Mastering Markdown
==================

[ []{.octicon .octicon-clock} 3 minute read ]{.article-read-time
.article-meta} [[]{.octicon .octicon-cloud-download} Download PDF
version](/pdfs/markdown-cheatsheet-online.pdf){.article-pdf
.article-meta}

</div>

</div>

<div class="wrap">

<div class="toc-wrapper">

</div>

<div class="markdown-body content-body">

[]{#intro .toc-item} Markdown is a lightweight and easy-to-use syntax
for styling all forms of writing on the GitHub platform.

**What you will learn:**

-   How the Markdown format makes styled collaborative editing easy
-   How Markdown differs from traditional formatting approaches
-   How to use Markdown to format text
-   How to leverage GitHub’s automatic Markdown rendering
-   How to apply GitHub’s unique Markdown extensions

[]{#what .toc-item}

What is Markdown?
-----------------

[Markdown](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/) is a way to
style text on the web. You control the display of the document;
formatting words as bold or italic, adding images, and creating lists
are just a few of the things we can do with Markdown. Mostly, Markdown
is just regular text with a few non-alphabetic characters thrown in,
like `#`{.highlighter-rouge} or `*`{.highlighter-rouge}.

You can use Markdown most places around GitHub:

-   [Gists](https://gist.github.com/)
-   Comments in Issues and Pull Requests
-   Files with the `.md`{.highlighter-rouge} or
    `.markdown`{.highlighter-rouge} extension

For more information, see “[Writing on
GitHub](https://help.github.com/categories/writing-on-github/)” in the
*GitHub Help*.

[]{#examples .toc-item}

Examples
--------

-   [Text](#){.selected}
-   [Lists](#)
-   [Images](#)
-   [Headers & Quotes](#)
-   [Code](#)
-   [Extras](#)

<div id="example-text" class="markdown-example">

``` {.source}
It's very easy to make some words **bold** and other words *italic* with
Markdown. You can even [link to Google!](http://google.com)
```

<div class="rendered">

It's very easy to make some words **bold** and other words *italic* with
Markdown. You can even [link to Google!](http://google.com)

</div>

</div>

<div id="example-lists" class="markdown-example" style="display:none">

``` {.source}
Sometimes you want numbered lists:

1. One
2. Two
3. Three

Sometimes you want bullet points:

* Start a line with a star
* Profit!

Alternatively,

- Dashes work just as well
- And if you have sub points, put two spaces before the dash or star:
  - Like this
  - And this
```

<div class="rendered">

Sometimes you want numbered lists:

1.  One
2.  Two
3.  Three

Sometimes you want bullet points:

-   Start a line with a star
-   Profit!

Alternatively,

-   Dashes work just as well
-   And if you have sub points, put two spaces before the dash or star:
    -   Like this
    -   And this

</div>

</div>

<div id="example-images" class="markdown-example" style="display:none">

``` {.source}
If you want to embed images, this is how you do it:

![Image of Yaktocat](https://octodex.github.com/images/yaktocat.png)
```

<div class="rendered">

If you want to embed images, this is how you do it:

![Image of Yakotocat](https://octodex.github.com/images/yaktocat.png)

</div>

</div>

<div id="example-headers" class="markdown-example" style="display:none">

``` {.source}
# Structured documents

Sometimes it's useful to have different levels of headings to structure your
documents. Start lines with a `#` to create headings. Multiple `##` in a row
denote smaller heading sizes.

### This is a third-tier heading

You can use one `#` all the way up to `######` six for different heading sizes.

If you'd like to quote someone, use the > character before the line:

> Coffee. The finest organic suspension ever devised... I beat the Borg with
> it.
> - Captain Janeway
```

<div class="rendered">

Structured documents
====================

Sometimes it’s useful to have different levels of headings to structure
your documents. Start lines with a `#` to create headings. Multiple `##`
in a row denote smaller heading sizes.

### This is a third-tier heading

You can use one `#` all the way up to `######` six for different heading
sizes.

If you’d like to quote someone, use the &gt; character before the line:

> Coffee. The finest organic suspension ever devised… I beat the Borg
> with it. - Captain Janeway

</div>

</div>

<div id="example-code" class="markdown-example" style="display:none">

```` {.source}
There are many different ways to style code with GitHub's markdown. If you have
inline code blocks, wrap them in backticks: `var example = true`.  If you've
got a longer block of code, you can indent with four spaces:

    if (isAwesome){
      return true
    }

GitHub also supports something called code fencing, which allows for multiple
lines without indentation:

```
if (isAwesome){
  return true
}
```

And if you'd like to use syntax highlighting, include the language:

```javascript
if (isAwesome){
  return true
}
```
````

<div class="rendered">

There are many different ways to style code with GitHub’s markdown. If
you have inline code blocks, wrap them in backticks:
`var example = true`. If you’ve got a longer block of code, you can
indent with four spaces:

    if (isAwesome){
      return true
    }

GitHub also supports something called code fencing, which allows for
multiple lines without indentation:

    if (isAwesome){
      return true
    }

And if you’d like to use syntax highlighting, include the language:

<div class="highlight highlight-javascript">

    if (isAwesome){
      return true
    }

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="example-extras" class="markdown-example" style="display:none">

``` {.source}
GitHub supports many extras in Markdown that help you reference and link to
people. If you ever want to direct a comment at someone, you can prefix their
name with an @ symbol: Hey @kneath — love your sweater!

But I have to admit, tasks lists are my favorite:

- [x] This is a complete item
- [ ] This is an incomplete item

When you include a task list in the first comment of an Issue, you will see a
helpful progress bar in your list of issues. It works in Pull Requests, too!

And, of course emoji! :sparkles: :camel: :boom:
```

<div class="rendered">

GitHub supports many extras in Markdown that help you reference and link
to people. If you ever want to direct a comment at someone, you can
prefix their name with an @ symbol: Hey
[@kneath](https://github.com/kneath){.user-mention} — love your sweater!

But I have to admit, tasks lists are my favorite:

-   This is a complete item
-   This is an incomplete item

When you include a task list in the first comment of an Issue, you will
see a helpful progress bar in your list of issues. It works in Pull
Requests, too!

And, of course emoji!
![:sparkles:](https://assets-cdn.github.com/images/icons/emoji/unicode/2728.png
":sparkles:"){.emoji
width="20" height="20"}
![:camel:](https://assets-cdn.github.com/images/icons/emoji/unicode/1f42b.png
":camel:"){.emoji
width="20" height="20"}
![:boom:](https://assets-cdn.github.com/images/icons/emoji/unicode/1f4a5.png
":boom:"){.emoji
width="20" height="20"}

</div>

</div>

[]{#syntax .toc-item}

Syntax guide
------------

Here’s an overview of Markdown syntax that you can use anywhere on
GitHub.com or in your own text files.

### Headers

<div class="language-markdown highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
# This is an <h1> tag
## This is an <h2> tag
###### This is an <h6> tag
```

</div>

</div>

### Emphasis

<div class="language-markdown highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
*This text will be italic*
_This will also be italic_

**This text will be bold**
__This will also be bold__

_You **can** combine them_
```

</div>

</div>

### Lists

#### Unordered

<div class="language-markdown highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
* Item 1
* Item 2
  * Item 2a
  * Item 2b
```

</div>

</div>

#### Ordered

<div class="language-markdown highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
1. Item 1
1. Item 2
1. Item 3
   1. Item 3a
   1. Item 3b
```

</div>

</div>

### Images

<div class="language-markdown highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
![GitHub Logo](/images/logo.png)
Format: ![Alt Text](url)
```

</div>

</div>

### Links

<div class="language-markdown highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
http://github.com - automatic!
[GitHub](http://github.com)
```

</div>

</div>

### Blockquotes

<div class="language-markdown highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
As Kanye West said:

> We're living the future so
> the present is our past.
```

</div>

</div>

### Inline code

<div class="highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
I think you should use an
`<addr>` element here instead.
```

</div>

</div>

[]{#GitHub-flavored-markdown .toc-item}

GitHub Flavored Markdown
------------------------

GitHub.com uses its own version of the Markdown syntax that provides an
additional set of useful features, many of which make it easier to work
with content on GitHub.com.

Note that some features of GitHub Flavored Markdown are only available
in the descriptions and comments of Issues and Pull Requests. These
include @mentions as well as references to SHA-1 hashes, Issues, and
Pull Requests. Task Lists are also available in Gist comments and in
Gist Markdown files.

### Syntax highlighting

Here’s an example of how you can use syntax highlighting with [GitHub
Flavored
Markdown](https://help.github.com/articles/basic-writing-and-formatting-syntax/):

<div class="highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

```` {.highlight}
```javascript
function fancyAlert(arg) {
  if(arg) {
    $.facebox({div:'#foo'})
  }
}
```
````

</div>

</div>

You can also simply indent your code by four spaces:

<div class="highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
    function fancyAlert(arg) {
      if(arg) {
        $.facebox({div:'#foo'})
      }
    }
```

</div>

</div>

Here’s an example of Python code without syntax highlighting:

<div class="highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
def foo():
    if not bar:
        return True
```

</div>

</div>

### Task Lists

<div class="highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
- [x] @mentions, #refs, [links](), **formatting**, and <del>tags</del>
  supported
- [x] list syntax required (any unordered or ordered list supported)
- [x] this is a complete item
- [ ] this is an incomplete item
```

</div>

</div>

If you include a task list in the first comment of an Issue, you will
get a handy progress indicator in your issue list. It also works in Pull
Requests!

### Tables

You can create tables by assembling a list of words and dividing them
with hyphens `-`{.highlighter-rouge} (for the first row), and then
separating each column with a pipe `|`{.highlighter-rouge}:

<div class="highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
First Header | Second Header
------------ | -------------
Content from cell 1 | Content from cell 2
Content in the first column | Content in the second column
```

</div>

</div>

Would become:

  First Header                  Second Header
  ----------------------------- ------------------------------
  Content from cell 1           Content from cell 2
  Content in the first column   Content in the second column

### SHA references

Any reference to a commit’s [SHA-1
hash](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SHA-1) will be automatically
converted into a link to that commit on GitHub.

<div class="highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
16c999e8c71134401a78d4d46435517b2271d6ac
mojombo@16c999e8c71134401a78d4d46435517b2271d6ac
mojombo/github-flavored-markdown@16c999e8c71134401a78d4d46435517b2271d6ac
```

</div>

</div>

### Issue references within a repository

Any number that refers to an Issue or Pull Request will be automatically
converted into a link.

<div class="highlighter-rouge">

<div class="highlight">

``` {.highlight}
#1
mojombo#1
mojombo/github-flavored-markdown#1
```

</div>

</div>

### Username @mentions

Typing an `@`{.highlighter-rouge} symbol, followed by a username, will
notify that person to come and view the comment. This is called an
“@mention”, because you’re *mentioning* the individual. You can also
@mention teams within an organization.

### Automatic linking for URLs

Any URL (like `http://www.github.com/`{.highlighter-rouge}) will be
automatically converted into a clickable link.

### Strikethrough

Any word wrapped with two tildes (like `~~this~~`{.highlighter-rouge})
will appear crossed out.

### Emoji

GitHub supports
[emoji](https://help.github.com/articles/basic-writing-and-formatting-syntax/#using-emoji)!
![:sparkles:](https://assets-cdn.github.com/images/icons/emoji/unicode/2728.png
":sparkles:"){.emoji
width="20" height="20"}
![:camel:](https://assets-cdn.github.com/images/icons/emoji/unicode/1f42b.png
":camel:"){.emoji
width="20" height="20"}
![:boom:](https://assets-cdn.github.com/images/icons/emoji/unicode/1f4a5.png
":boom:"){.emoji
width="20" height="20"}

To see a list of every image we support, check out the [Emoji Cheat
Sheet](https://github.com/ikatyang/emoji-cheat-sheet/blob/master/README.md).

Last updated Jan 15, 2014

</div>

</div>
